text: {| |} Indian was launched at Workington in 1820. She traded widely, and between 1828 an 1831 or so made several voyages to Singapore, Batavia, and Manila under a license from the British East India Company (EIC). She was wrecked around 1843. ==Career== Indian first appeared in Lloyd's Register (LR) in 1820.LR (1820), Supple. pages "I/J", Seq.№I/J92. {| class=" wikitable" |- ! Year ! Master ! Owner ! Trade ! Source |- | 1820 | R.Fells | Woods & Co. | Workington–Liverpool | LR |- | 1821 | R.Fell A.Morris | Wood & Co | Workington–Liverpool Liverpool– | |- | 1823 | A.Morris | Buchanan | Liverpool–Buenos Aires | LR |- | 1827 | Eadie Scott | Buchanan | London–Jamaica | LR |- | 1829 | W.Eadie J.Harding | Wise | London–Batavia |LR |- | 1830 | J.Harding | Wise | Liverpool–Singapore | LR| |} In 1813 the EIC had lost its monopoly on the trade between India and Britain. British ships were then free to sail to India or the Indian Ocean under a license from the EIC. On 27 July 1828 Captain Eadie sailed for Batavia and Singapore under a license from the EIC.LR (1829), "Ships trading to India – 1828". Then on 31 October 1829 Captain Harding sailed there too. On 15 August 1831 Captain W. Ravenscroft sailed Indian to Batavia and Manilla. {| class=" wikitable" |- ! Year ! Master ! Owner ! Trade | Homeport ! Source & notes |- | 1835 | L.Mackay | J.Ritson | Liverpool–Quebec | London Maryport | LR |- | 1840 | J.Feiron | J.Ritson | Maryport–North America | Maryport | LR; small repairs 1839 & 1840 |- | 1843 | J.Scott | J.Ritson | Maryport–Liverpool | Maryport | LR; small repairs 1839 & 1840 |- |} ==Fate== Her entry in the 1843 volume of LR has the annotation "Wrecked" by her name.LR (1843), Seq.№I43. ==Citations and references== Citations References * Category:1820 ships Category:Ships built in England Category:Age of Sail merchant ships of England Category:Maritime incidents in 1843
